body:
I think i've encountered the same issue, here is my bug reproduction script:

```ruby
gem 'activerecord', '3.2.3'
require 'active_record'
require 'logger'

# Print out what version we're running
puts "Active Record #{ActiveRecord::VERSION::STRING}"

ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)

# Connect to an in-memory sqlite3 database
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection( :adapter  => 'sqlite3',
                                         :database => ':memory:' )

# Create the minimal database schema necessary to reproduce the bug
ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table "users" do |t|
  end

  create_table "bugs" do |t|
    t.integer :user_id
    t.integer :dog_id
  end

  create_table "dogs" do |t|
  end
end

# Create the minimal set of models to reproduce the bug
class Dog < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :bugs
end

class Bug < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :user
  belongs_to :dog
  scope :with_dog, joins(:dog) # XXX: does not work through associations!
  scope :with_dog_indeed, joins('INNER JOIN "dogs" ON "dogs"."id" = "bugs"."dog_id"') # this produces identical SQL in itself and works through associations
end

class User < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :bugs
  scope :with_dogs, joins(:bugs).merge(Bug.with_dog)               # does not work
  scope :with_dogs_indeed, joins(:bugs).merge(Bug.with_dog_indeed) # works
end

# Working code examples:
puts Bug.with_dog.to_sql == Bug.with_dog_indeed.to_sql # output: true
puts User.with_dogs_indeed.to_sql # output: SELECT "users".* FROM "users" INNER JOIN "bugs" ON "bugs"."user_id" = "users"."id" INNER JOIN "dogs" ON "dogs"."id" = "bugs"."dog_id"

# THE BUG:
User.with_dogs
# ActiveRecord::ConfigurationError: Association named 'dog' was not found; perhaps you misspelled it?
```
